I really enjoyed this class. The content I found super interesting and enlightening-and it definitely made me think about diseases in a more public health mind-frame as opposed to the biological-only mind-frame I have always been used to. That being said, I think there could be more organization of the class as in-a book. A lot of the material covered in class is biological mechanisms, and but the literature assigned does not usually explain it well and we discuss it for a bit, and the move on. And classes aren't recorded so we can't go back and review it that way either. I think there is a lot of important content. But I think we move through it too quickly for a good understanding. This easily could be an every day course for multiple semesters to really get a good understanding.

This course is a great introduction to infectious diseases. I am not in EMD and have very little biology background, which made learning the concepts slightly more challenging. However, the combination of the biological, epidemiological, and social factors of infectious disease made the course interesting and useful.
Great course. TFs and instructor are great and there seems to be a system to this course that has worked historically so no suggestions from me.

This course helped me to look at the infectious diseases in a broader aspect. Also, sometimes everyone were listing one point and Dr. Pettigrew was commenting but at the end of the class I was feeling that I couldn't understand the main point. Especially with the empty slides, it was not easy to remember all the things that we have talked when you are not sure which one was correct. And I had really hard times with Dr. Childs' lectures.

Good course

STRENGTHS:
Excellent overview of infectious diseases, touching on very relevant ID principles from a public health perspective. Very "balanced" approach.
Loved the engagement with current literature regarding ID topics, facilitated by an excellent instructor.
Given my science background, I appreciated the biological/mechanistic details offered throughout the course.

The first HW was graded somewhat harshly, but overall very fair and useful assessments. Fair exams testing general concepts.
Enjoyed the in-class discussions, but during the first few months, I felt like "balance" was lost in that too much time was spent discussing individual students' opinions, resulting in alot of "rushing through" the last few slides of each lecture. By the end of the semester, this balance was restored.


WEAKNESSES:
During the first 1.5 months, a couple comments seemed to denigrate physician involvement in infectious diseases; while I realize the important contribution the medical community has had towards antimicrobial resistance and other public health issues,  given the generally existing anti-physician sentiment among the YSPH student population, I felt like a more balanced discussion could have been facilitated. This, however, seemed restored by the end of the semester.

STRENGTHS
-- I appreciated the opportunities to work in small groups, especially given the size of the class. The more of that, the better. I also appreciated the professors emphasis on asking and answering questions of students, again very gracefully done given the size of the class. These were important moments for us to engage with the material and retrieve information from our memories to strengthen our understanding.
-- I loved that the homework assignments gave us the chance to think through problems, work with classmates, and prepare for the exams. The study guides for exams were also very helpful  if you studied based off the study guide, you both understood the material better and could pass the test. I had a class on a related topic the same semester, and the only questions I could answer on the exams for that class were the ones I had had homework assignments on in Principles of Infectious Diseases, because the homework assignments stuck the material into my brain.
-- Giving students open-ended questions to grapple with is a great idea, as long as theyre vetted by TAs first of course. This course did a great job of connecting biological processes to larger epidemiological questions. 

WEAKNESSES
-- The most helpful way to organize course readings on Canvas is in a File, which can be downloaded in its entirety, and then easily accessed when offline or facing slow internet access. Modules and links to external websites are a challenge to navigate, and can require signing in with Yales Virtual Private Network when off-campus to gain access to some articles, which can in turn require Multifactor Authentication. It is easier to download all the files for each class in one go, and that is best done when they are all included in a folder in Files. 
-- The professor noted that the scores on the first exam were separated into two tiers. If I had to take a guess, I would guess that the upper tier is people who had a background in biology and whose first language was English, and vice versa for the lower tier. More definitions of terms during lectures would help those who dont already have that body of knowledge.
strong in ID.

Good instructor who selected very relevant, public health topics throughout the course for individuals with and without science backgrounds.
- a few of the mechanistic details seemed overbearing towards SBS individuals towards the beginning of the course, but this was rectified by the end.

STRENGTHS
-- The professor was very organized and gave interesting lectures, with well-structured PowerPoints.
-- The professor had a friendly and relaxed way of speaking to students that put us at ease and helped us to learn. She was responsive to student emails.
-- The professor structured the class in such a way that those of us who attended lectures learned more than those who did not  which is how learning should be. Were not here to get what we could get just from reading a textbook, we like to hear what she has to say.

WEAKNESSES
-- The professor sometimes would speak quickly during important points, or use terminology that students were not familiar with and then lose half the audience. Assume that every word needs to be defined the first two times its used in a lecture, for example slowly say episome, a genetic element inside some bacterial cells rather than just episome.
very engaging lecturer, and creates a very conducive learning environment.

Prof. Pettigrew was a great lecturer teaching us very interesting material. My one point would be sometimes I felt the lectures were too long or rushed and we couldnt cover some material in detail. Sometimes it was also hard to take notes completely as the slides would go by real quickly.

She is a brilliant instructor and I feel lucky to learn from her. The only comment I would leave is to ask her to be mindful of those with less medical literacy. The first few weeks of class I was googling words as she said them because, not coming straight from undergrad or a microbio background, even words like serotype needed a brush up for me. Therefore I got behind a lot because I did not have the background knowledge that she assumed we all had when learned biological mechanisms and I felt it harmed me in note taking. Because she does write what she says on the slides, if you are not comprehending as you are writing your notes are almost worthless and I felt it would be more helpful for students like me to start slower and spell things out more clearly. However, she was very good about checking in with us to make sure we understood.
